natural problem: Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor?
natural solution: The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> B \<and> y \<in> B \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow>
  (\<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd x) \<and> (\<nexists> q. prime q \<and> q < p \<and> q dvd y)"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor = 58"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> B \<and> y \<in> B \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow>
  (\<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd x) \<and> (\<nexists> q. prime q \<and> q < p \<and> q dvd y)"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor = 58"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There is a set of integers B that includes {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}. For every pair of distinct numbers x and y in B, there exists a prime number p that divides x, and there is no prime number q less than p that divides y. What is the smallest prime factor in this set? The answer is 58.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall>b. b \<in> B \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>p. prime p \<and> p dvd b)"
shows  "Min ((\<lambda>b. Min {p. prime p \<and> p dvd b}) ` B) = 58"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall>b. b \<in> B \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>p. prime p \<and> p dvd b)"
shows  "Min ((\<lambda>b. Min {p. prime p \<and> p dvd b}) ` B) = 58"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a set B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}, find the smallest number in the set such that there exists a prime number that divides it. The final answer is 58.

a_2.formal problem:
datatype number = Number int

fun prime :: "int ⇒ bool" where
  "prime x = (if x > 1 then (\<forall> i ∈ {2..<x}. x mod i ≠ 0) else False)"

fun smallest_prime_factor :: "int ⇒ int" where
  "smallest_prime_factor x = (if x > 1 then (LEAST p. prime p ∧ x mod p = 0) else x)"

definition B :: "number set" where
  "B = {Number 55, Number 57, Number 58, Number 59, Number 61}"

definition smallest_prime_in_B :: "int" where
  "smallest_prime_in_B = (LEAST x. ∃ n ∈ B. smallest_prime_factor (case n of Number m ⇒ m) = x)"

theorem "smallest_prime_in_B = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

datatype number = Number int

fun prime :: "int ⇒ bool" where
  "prime x = (if x > 1 then (\<forall> i ∈ {2..<x}. x mod i ≠ 0) else False)"

fun smallest_prime_factor :: "int ⇒ int" where
  "smallest_prime_factor x = (if x > 1 then (LEAST p. prime p ∧ x mod p = 0) else x)"

definition B :: "number set" where
  "B = {Number 55, Number 57, Number 58, Number 59, Number 61}"

definition smallest_prime_in_B :: "int" where
  "smallest_prime_in_B = (LEAST x. ∃ n ∈ B. smallest_prime_factor (case n of Number m ⇒ m) = x)"

theorem "smallest_prime_in_B = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a set B consisting of the numbers 55, 57, 58, 59, and 61. Define a prime number as a number greater than 1 that has no divisors other than 1 and itself, and define the smallest prime factor of a number as the smallest prime that divides it. What is the smallest prime factor to appear among the numbers in set B? The final answer is 2.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x ∈ B ⟶ y ∈ B ⟶ (Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd x}) ≤ (Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd y})"
shows  "Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd x} = 2" when "x = 58"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x ∈ B ⟶ y ∈ B ⟶ (Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd x}) ≤ (Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd y})"
shows  "Min {p. prime p ∧ p dvd x} = 2" when "x = 58"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a set B of natural numbers {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}. For every pair of numbers x and y from the set B, it is given that the smallest prime number which divides x is less than or equal to the smallest prime number which divides y. What is the smallest prime number that divides 58? The answer is 2.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "int set" and smallest_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x \<in> B. smallest_prime x = (LEAST p. prime p \<and> p dvd x)"
shows  "(LEAST x. x \<in> B \<and> smallest_prime x = smallest_prime 58) = 58"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "int set" and smallest_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x \<in> B. smallest_prime x = (LEAST p. prime p \<and> p dvd x)"
shows  "(LEAST x. x \<in> B \<and> smallest_prime x = smallest_prime 58) = 58"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Let $B$ be the set of integers {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}. For each number $x$ in $B$, let's define the smallest prime number that divides $x$ as $smallest\_prime(x)$. What is the smallest number in set $B$ for which the smallest prime number that divides it is the same as the smallest prime number that divides 58? The final answer is 58.

a_5.formal problem:
definition B :: "int set" where "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
theorem smallest_prime_factor_in_B:
fixes B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> B. \<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd n"
shows  "LEAST n. \<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd n \<and> n \<in> B = 58"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem smallest_prime_factor_in_B:
fixes B :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> B. \<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd n"
shows  "LEAST n. \<exists> p. prime p \<and> p dvd n \<and> n \<in> B = 58"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: For the set B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}, each number in B has at least one prime number that divides it. What is the smallest number in B that has a prime number dividing it? The final answer is 58.

a_6.formal problem:
datatype Prime = Prime nat

primrec smallest_prime :: "Prime \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"smallest_prime (Prime n) = (if is_prime n then n else smallest_prime (Prime (n - 1)))"

definition B :: "nat set" where
"B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"

value "(LEAST n. n \<in> B \<and> (smallest_prime (Prime n) = n))"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

datatype Prime = Prime nat

primrec smallest_prime :: "Prime \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"smallest_prime (Prime n) = (if is_prime n then n else smallest_prime (Prime (n - 1)))"

definition B :: "nat set" where
"B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"

value "(LEAST n. n \<in> B \<and> (smallest_prime (Prime n) = n))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the smallest prime number in the set {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "nat set" and min_prime_factor :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a \<noteq> b \<longrightarrow> min_prime_factor a \<noteq> min_prime_factor b"
shows  "min_prime_factor 58 = Min (min_prime_factor ` B)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "nat set" and min_prime_factor :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> a \<noteq> b \<longrightarrow> min_prime_factor a \<noteq> min_prime_factor b"
shows  "min_prime_factor 58 = Min (min_prime_factor ` B)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a set B of natural numbers {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}, and assuming that no two different numbers in B have the same smallest prime factor, find the smallest prime factor of 58. The smallest prime factor of 58 should also be the smallest prime factor among all numbers in B.

a_8.formal problem:
datatype nat_set = B

fun smallest_prime_factor :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" where 
"smallest_prime_factor B = (LEAST x. is_prime x \<and> x dvd B)"

theorem
fixes B :: "nat_set"
and set_B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "set_B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> set_B. \<exists> p. is_prime p \<and> p dvd n"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor 58 \<le> smallest_prime_factor n"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

datatype nat_set = B

fun smallest_prime_factor :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" where 
"smallest_prime_factor B = (LEAST x. is_prime x \<and> x dvd B)"

theorem
fixes B :: "nat_set"
and set_B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "set_B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> set_B. \<exists> p. is_prime p \<and> p dvd n"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor 58 \<le> smallest_prime_factor n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: For a set of natural numbers {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}, suppose every number in this set has at least one prime number as a factor. Prove that the smallest prime factor of 58 is less than or equal to the smallest prime factor of any number in the set.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes B :: "int set" and smallest_prime_factor :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> B \<and> y \<in> B \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> smallest_prime_factor x \<ge> smallest_prime_factor y"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor 58 \<le> smallest_prime_factor x"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Set $B = \{55, 57, 58, 59, 61\}.$  Which number in set B has the smallest prime factor? The final Answer is 58
 ### Proof
 The smallest prime is 2, which is a factor of every even number. Because $\boxed{58}$ is the only even number, it has the smallest prime factor.
 *)

theorem
fixes B :: "int set" and smallest_prime_factor :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "B = {55, 57, 58, 59, 61}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> B \<and> y \<in> B \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> smallest_prime_factor x \<ge> smallest_prime_factor y"
shows  "smallest_prime_factor 58 \<le> smallest_prime_factor x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If the set B contains the integers 55, 57, 58, 59, and 61, and for any two different numbers x and y in this set, the smallest prime factor of x is greater than or equal to the smallest prime factor of y, then the smallest prime factor of 58 is less than or equal to the smallest prime factor of any number in the set.
